DS Smith PLC (SMDS:LSE): Last: 364.96, up 21.76 (+6.34%), High: 366.00, Low: 331.70, Volume: 7.79m
JP11:19am

Up on better expected final year results.

11:19 am
JP11:19am

Here's Peel Hunt:

JP11:19am

DS Smith (Buy, TP 460p) - Finals in line and margin targets go up
The final results are very much as expected, with operating profit of £631m comparing to our forecast of £630m. Organic corrugated volumes were up 2.4% in a market up 1.9%, which is slightly behind the company’s target of beating by 100bps but there was some weakness in Germany through the second half. The operating margin of 10.2% was better than expected (we had 9.9%) but this was indicated at the pre-close in April. Europac synergies have been increased to €70m from €50m and the margin target has been increased to 10% to 12% from 8% to 10%. On a pro-forma basis with Plastics sold, leverage is just under 2x. In terms of the outlook, the company remains confident about volume and market share growth. There has been some weakness in certain export led markets including Germany and there is recognition of some volatility in input costs but progress is expected this year. We are bottom end of expectations at 38.0p and don’t expect this to change in a major way.

Viking1 Majestic ? Chairman gone and Divi?

Omikin Hello internet people!

JP11:21am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: DS Smith reported FY H2 2019 (ending April 30) revenues of £3.1b, adjusted EBITA of £327m (consensus according to the company £326m) and an adjusted EPS (also adding back amortization as per company definition) of £16.9p (consensus according to the company 16.8p).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Net debt/EBITDA (company definition) at the end of FY 2019 stood at 2.3x versus earlier guidance of below 2.3x and UBSe at 2.2x (no consensus available). The proposed dividend per share for FY H2 2019 was 11.0p (UBSe: 10.5p).

More from the renown Swiss bank:

11:22 am
JP11:22am

Q: Has the company’s outlook/guidance changed?
A: DS Smith expects further good progress in the coming year, indicating EBITA growth. Volumes growth is expected to improve from a weaker FY H2 19 and the company expected to gain further market share. The current consensus for FY 2020E adjusted EBITA is at £725m, representing a 15% growth to the £631m reported in FY 2019. The company upgraded its synergy target for the Europac acquisition (driven by reduced head office costs and paper optimisation) from £50m to £70m (we assume the time frame remains the same, i.e. by end CY 2021). DS Smith also upgraded its mid-term return on sales target (adjusted EBITA margin) from 8-10% to 10-12% (10.2% in FY 2019, we have c.10% for FY 2020E-24E). IFRS 16 (Leasing) will add £235m in debt (UBSe: 160m) and increase EBITDA by £75m (UBSe: 30m) in FY 2020E.

Patience @JP - rather it was weird how unloved the shares were until 10:30 today!
Pharma @red, but it won't be a deal based on the WA.
JP11:23am

Valuation: Neutral, PT 336p; How would we expect investors to react?
A: FY H2 2019 earnings were well aligned with consensus expectations and outlook comments much as expected, we believe. Upgrading the synergy target was a slight positive, but expected based on earlier comments by the company, and the same goes for the EBITA margin target. At first glance, we would not expect consensus FY 2020E EBITA to move much, but mid-term margins might increase a bit. The share is up by 15% year-to-date and by 9% during the last two weeks alone, and we would therefore not expect to see much additional outperformance today. No meaningful read-across to peers.

JP11:26am

Here's Deutsche on the deal -- which would see the private equity group buy out the Germany media company's minority shareholders, valuing the business at around €6.7bn.

JP11:27am

KKR's offer and a profit downgrade due to Stepstone all on the same day
KKR confirmed this morning that it would be making a public takeover offer for Axel
Springer at EUR63 per share, corresponding to a market value of ~EUR6.8bn for
Springer and a multiple of 11.3x on EV/EBITDA 2019E (on our new EBITDA estimate
for 2019E). The offer comes less than two weeks after Springer confirmed that it
was in fact negotiating with KKR and corresponds to a premium of ~40% from the
date prior to the release (29 May). The rationale appears clear, Springer wants to
invest in its businesses, significantly so, and KKR is ready to be a partner for at least

five years while the investments are made and growth is reaped. KKR is also pre-
pared to support Springer's inorganic growth strategy if and when opportunities do

arise. We await more information around the offer acceptance period with the offi-
cial offer document that is yet to be published but move our target price to EUR63

in line with the current offer price and maintain our Hold rating.

Excel Developer #Brexit: Shouldn't GBP be lower no that Parliament has fluffed last chance to avoid no deal?
11:27 am
JP11:27am

There could be more opportunities for consolidation in European classifieds
With a revised outlook today due to worse-than-expected macro headwinds taking
a toll on Stepstone's growth in 2019, and with the outlook for more investments to
come in 2020 after two years of investment already, we think investors may be more
receptive to KKR's offer. The acceptance threshold is also low at 20% given that KKR
already has the backing of the major shareholders, Friede Springer (42.6% stake)

and CEO Mathias Doepfner (2.8%) who will continue to act as controlling share-
holders with KKR. The bid by KKR for Springer is the second in the Classifieds space

in Germany after Scout24 (Buy) was bid for by Hellman & Friedman and The Black-
stone Group earlier this year (the offer lapsed due to the acceptance threshold not

being met).

JP11:28am

We summarize the new outlook and our estimates below. We lower our 2019E adj.
EBITDA by ~3% which amounts to a 3% yoy decline (vs. the outlook which calls for
a decline in the mid single-digit percentage range). We also lower our 2020E adj.

EBITDA more substantially by ~13% taking it to a 3% decline vs. 2019E (vs. man-
agement expectations for a substantially lower 2020E adj. EBITDA vs. 2019E). Man-
agement then expects adj. EBITDA in 2021 to be substantially better than 2020E

(DBe up 16% yoy).

AMALtd @Excel: You wont see any impactful in GBP before Boris gest in or before Oct 31st. Fed Rates hike incoming

And for good measure, here's UBS:

Excel Developer @AMALtd: USD Futures strip shows FED rate CUTS
11:28 am
JP11:29am

KKR announces the launch of a public takeover offer for €63 per share

This morning, Axel Springer has entered into an Investment Agreement with KKR, Friede Springer and CEO Mathias Dopfner (who both have 45% of the share capital) to launch a public takeover offer to remaining minority shareholders at an offer price of €63 per share. The offer represents a 31.5% premium to the 3-mth unaffected VWAP. The Executive Board and Supervisory Board have said they support the public takeover offer, subject to review of the offer document. The offer is subject to a minimum acceptance rate of 20%, merger control clearance and other regulatory approvals. Friede Springer and Mathias Dopfner have also stated they will refrain from accepting the public takeover offer, but will continue to be involved in Axel Springer.

JP11:29am

Offer implies a valuation for Classifieds Media of ~25x FY19E PE

In the statement this morning, Axel Springer has also cut FY19 guidance as a result of weak revenue development, especially in Jobs due to a weaker macro environment and the digital tax passed in France. Axel Springer now expects organic revenue for Classifieds to grow mid to high single digit (UBSe +8.8%) vs prev. HSD to LDD and EBITDA to fall MSD on a reported basis (UBSe +1%, cons flat) vs stable before. Further, Axel Springer indicated group EBITDA in 2020 will be significantly below 2019 (UBSe +4.5%, cons +6%) and to improve significantly thereafter. As a result, we expect cons EPS downgrades in the range of -6-10% in FY19E and double digit in 2020E. After factoring in FY19 guidance downgrades, the offer price of €63 per share implies a valuation for Classifieds Media of ~25x FY19 PE, at the low end of the peer group of 25-30x (Scout24 26x, Autotrader 25x, Rightmove 30x).

JP11:29am

Offer is attractive in light of the guidance downgrade and our €56.50 PT

We believe the offer is attractive in light of the guidance downgrade in 2019 and our price target of €56.50. Further, the offer price values Axel Springer's classifieds assets on 25x FY19 PE, at the low-end of the peer group, vs historically trading at a discount to reflect the cyclicality of jobs and less favourable asset mix.

Here's Macquarie:

JP11:33am

UK&ROI further investing in price & range: UK LFL came in 0.4% vs. Cons. +0.5% (though BBRG at +0.8%). Ireland LFL came in at 1.3%. TSCO made further investments in price and range in Q1, and saw particularly strong performance in Easter. UK volume has outperformed the market by +1.3%.
Booker lapping contract wins: Booker LFL came in at 3.1%, now lapping one-off contract wins last year. Customers responded well to improved fresh food offer with a two-year LFL of 17.4%.

Tom Dalgleish Drop in the ocean
JP11:33am

Central Europe & Asia: Central Europe came in at -4.9% while Asia was +0.1%. In Central Europe, Sunday trading ban in Poland and store closure impacted sales by -3ppts, not helped by the significantly cooler weather across the region impacted sales by c-2ppts. Asia posted its first positive LFL in two years. Thailand has seen an increased market share with strong growth in Bangkok.
Outlook unchanged: While there is no specific outlook comment, we do not expect any changes to consensus estimates today.

JP11:34am

Finance geeks, feel free to shoot me down.

red tesco probably needs to dump CE. difficult mkt for it. sometimes best to move on
11:34 am
JP11:35am

Bernstein also weighing in:

JP11:35am

Q1 UK LFL (ex. fuel, ex. Booker) of +0.4% was -40bps behind consensus (+0.8%) and a -140bps slowdown versus Q4 (+1.7%). We were expecting a softer Q1 from weak Kantar till roll data, especially given the tough comps (+2.3% LFL). Hence our forecast of +0.3%, in line with what the number published. Consensus still had numbers as high as +2%, which would suggest some stale numbers in consensus. The +0.4% was in line with Kantar performance.

The recent weakness in Tesco shares would indicate an anticipation of this slowdown, in line with peers: Morrisons registered just +0.2% Retail LFL contribution in Q1, whilst Asda had -1.1% LFLs inc. cal and +0.5% ex-calendar (Tesco does not provide an ex-cal number). Tesco is outperforming its big-4 peers for the last 5 periods on Kantar data and also on LfLs.

Tesco outgrew the market in both sales (+0.2%) and volume terms: a whopping +1.3% ahead of supermarket peers (excluding Aldi & Lidl). That implies either new price cuts by Tesco, or more likely a strong shift to the new discount brands ('Exclusively at Tesco'). This will put pressure on the supermarket peers and be good for volume leverage in Tesco.

Excel Developer @red: 3!? but there are only 8 meetings a year and we have had 3 already. Also, don't they tend to move when they publish dot plots (asterisked) January 29 – 30 March 19 – 20*April / May 30 – 1 June 18 – 19*July 30 – 31 September 17 – 18*October 29 – 30 December 10 – 11*
JP11:35am

Booker LFL of +3.1% was -140bps behind Bernstein expectations (+4.5%). Non-tobacco performed slightly better at +4.2%. Whilst a big step down from the +11.1% achieved across FY18/19, we are now cycling through materially tougher comps (+14.3% in Q1 last year) as we annualize major contract wins last year and the P&H bankruptcy boost to cigarette volumes.

Asia LFL of +0.1% was +210bps ahead Bernstein expectations (-2.0%). These are early indications that Tesco are starting to turn around the top line, as well as having rebounded margins in H2 FY18/19.

Central Europe LFL of -4.9% was -390bps behind Bernstein expectations (-1.0%). The Polish market is suffering from fewer trading days in Poland from the new Sunday trading regulations, and this quarter there was also the impact of cooler weather (up to -2% impact).

JP11:37am

Citi to finish us off:

JP11:37am

UK Core LFL +0.4% with strong market volume outperformance — Tesco UK reported LFLs of +0.4% (vs. Citi +0.5%), representing a two year stack of +2.5%. Moreover Tesco continues to invest in its offer (including Centenary and clubcard offers, Jack’s lines into mainline stores and the launch of a permanent “Fresh 5” fruit/veg offer) driving a lower rate of inflation versus the market and a volume outperformance quantified as +130bps vs. the IRI-defined competitor set (excl. German discounters). We would view the print as indicative of broadly flat LFL volumes against a tough PY weather comp, leaving Tesco well positioned to continue its operational outperformance.
Booker strength with +4.2% LFL ex-tobacco — Booker posted LFLs of +3.1% inc. tobacco and +4.2% ex-tobacco (Citi +3.5%). This leaves the key non-tobacco metric on a two year stack of c.+16/+17%, as the wholesaler continues to make impressive progress into the teeth of a tougher HORECA end-market.

red sundat trading regs mask problem in poland. tesco has no usp, its expensive. they have no pricing power here. similar to what m&s suffered. diff mkt to uk.

JP11:38am

To continue with Citi:

11:38 am
JP11:38am

Underlying resilience in International — Asia LFLs of +0.1% highlight the continued recovery of the Thai business with market share gains and after eight quarters of successive LFL declines in the region. Europe LFLs of -4.9% continue to be adversely impacted by sales declines in Poland (fewer trading days, continued restructuring) and a PY weather impact of at least -2% across the region.
No change to numbers — While the presentational and non-cash impact of IFRS16 is yet to be reflected in the majority of market forecasts, we expect no change to the underlying consensus expectations. Our post-IFRS16 model is available on request.
“Eyes on the (cash) prize” — Notwithstanding quarterly volatility, weather impacts, etc. we think Tesco is increasingly “on the front foot” as it continues to drive value into its core UK offer. Across multiple quarters this should drive incremental volume thereby underpinning Tesco’s ability to drive FCF and the attractions of a 9% FY19/20E (calendar 2019) FCF Yield.

JP11:44am

Here's a Peel Hunt note which just landed in my inbox:

JP11:44am

Closing in on a majestic deal If management can get £100m for the Retail arm, then it is the sale of the century and the share price is about right. What could send the shares away from their current level? Building a firm track record of growth at Naked could mean that it warrants a wider multiple in time, but on the other hand the market’s long memory means that any slips will be disproportionately punished. The shareholder base will evolve and the big special dividend that will surely follow the disposal of Retail may mean that non-growth investors hold on, for now. Expecting much progress in the short term is optimistic though, and whilst we up our TP to reflect the probability that the Retail deal is done at an attractive price, this remains one to watch from the sidelines.

red whats up with the housebuilders today. is it politics?
11:44 am
JP11:44am

£11.3m of FY19 PBT – The Prelims had virtually been pre-announced back in March, so there was little to alarm us in the statement itself. The FY dividend has been postponed until the Majestic deal is done (we’ll return to distribution later), and Commercial returned to a more manageable level of sales loss in H2, but there wasn’t much to see here FY19 wise.

Soundbuy Morning..............
JP11:44am

The deal is in advanced discussions – According to reports in the press, good progress is being made regarding the sale of the Retail arm – £100m is a number that has appeared in a number of articles and it seems that there are three interested parties. The bidders can see something that we can’t. Majestic Retail is finding life very tough; this year’s £11m of EBIT is on a declining trend, and it doesn’t strike us that there is much fat in the business. A 10x EBIT multiple seems punchy, and we’d expect management to be delighted if it could secure a three figure sum. Debt would be paid down, but the majority of the cash would be used for future investment at Naked. There would still, though, be plenty left over for a serious special dividend: £25m (about 30p) would be our guess, but we’d emphasise that it is a guess. Management has not been drawn at all on this topic, which is fair enough at this stage of negotiations

JP11:45am

(@red -- Help to Buy report I think -- see Tom's post: https://ftalphavil...ady-able--to-buy/)

Flaneur On Trump - his calculation that tariffs on Mexico would force them to act also seems to be correct.On Gulf - yet another conveniently timed cassus belli..... starting to Douma head in... Just like in Syria though, I cannot see China letting Iran go under.
11:45 am
JP11:45am

Naked: the US now the majority of sales – No real change in strategic terms from what we learned from the CMD on Naked. Customer retention remains good and contribution is growing too. Naked will spend £26m this year on customer recruitment and their quality is improving. If Naked grows in a straight line (which obviously it won’t, but anyway...), then ‘repeat contribution’ could be £80m by FY25, and EBIT for Naked could be £20-30m. It would be growing very quickly at that time, and would be able to attract a chunky multiple, but there are many rivers to cross before it gets there.

A. M. @Soundbuy: morning.
JP11:45am

Jam today, jam tomorrow – If management can get the deal done this summer and pay a nice dividend then the picture gets clearer, but can it persuade enough growth funds that the future is bright to pay a multiple of sales for Naked? We wouldn’t be rushing out to invest, but with the Retail deal likely to please, the shares are about right for now, we think.

11:46 am
JP11:46am

Wine specialist Majestic Wine has announced preliminary results for the 52 weeks ending 1st April 2019 which are inline with the trading update at the end of March, where the company announced its new strategy, where it aims to dispose of the retail and commercial arms of the business and focus solely on Naked Wines.

Group revenues grew 6.3% to £506m, with group adjusted PBT of £11.3m, down 34% year-on-year (yoy) as a result of the accelerated investment in Naked Wines and lower retail profitability.

Naked Wine posted revenue growth of 14.5% to £178m and an adjusted operating profit of £6.7m, down 22.4%, as a result of investment in customer acquisition (£19m investment during the year, an increase of £5m on last year).The retail division Majestic Wine delivered underlying revenue growth of 1.5% to £268m and a reduced adjusted operating profit of £11.3m, down 15% yoy due to declining gross margins.

Flaneur *casus belli
Soundbuy Tad late............
JP11:46am

The company has suggested it is in advanced discussions about the potential sales of Majestic retail and commercial, which it is expected to finalise over the summer months. The company will need shareholder approval to dispose of the non-core parts of the business. The final dividend has been suspended, to be replaced with a special dividend equal to the final FY18 payment, conditional to the completed sale of Majestic.

The company has also announced the appointment of John Walden as Chairman. Mr Walden was previously CEO at Home Retail group, together with Nick Delvin as COO.

Just Group (JUST) has released a statement ahead of its AGM today. The company remains committed to its target of becoming capital self-sufficient by 2022 through a focus on a more capital efficient model and reducing new business strain.

The message is no different from what we saw at the Q1 update in May, but this update simply confirms that the changes are working to make the business more capital light and also reduce costs through the reduction or closure of some of the smaller loss-making parts of the group.

It is also worth noting some other key developments from recent days, with the announcement yesterday of a new CFO. Andy Parsons (currently Group Finance Director at LV=) will join the group in January 2020, filling one of the vacant management positions. The search for a permanent CEO continues and will be ‘expedited’ by the Chairman. In addition, a number of the members of the board have been buying shares in recent days, confirming their own belief in the strength of the underlying business.

JUST has had several well publicised issues over the last few years that have had significant impacts on the share price, but the underlying business remains one ideally placed for strong growth in bulk annuities and lifetime mortgages over the coming years.

The share price has fallen significantly below the reality of events and at a 2019F PER of 3.6x continues to fundamentally undervalue the group. Our fair value of 110p provides 120% upside from the current share price. We reiterate our BUY recommendation.

JP11:58am

In spite of improving fundamentals since the start of 2018, we have maintained our Sell call on
Twitter as valuation kept getting ahead of itself. As we entered 2019, we also continue to believe
Twitter is not spending enough to clean up its platform. Indeed, we believe that Twitter
continues to pick the easy way out on fixing its platform. Case in point, Twitter guided for
modest +20% cost growth in 2019, far less than Facebook’s +51% spending increase in 2018 and
planned +37% to +45% increase in 2019. Accordingly, Twitter still does not seem to be doing
enough to secure its platform, while its valuation remains as stretched as ever.
As such, ahead of 2Q 2019 earnings, now seems to be an especially opportune time to Sell
Twitter. Just based on the math, Twitter is approaching difficult top-line comps given the sharp
recovery in its U.S. business in 3Q 2018. As revenue growth is set to decelerate, cost growth is
also expected to ramp. Twitter came in low on expenses in 1Q 2019 due to the timing of projects
pushed later in the year. Now, it will need to accelerate spending in the next few quarters to
meet its full-year +20% cost growth guidance.

11:58 am
JP11:58am

So, Twitter may significantly ramp up expenses in 2Q 2019 before top-line growth decelerates in
3Q 2019. It may also give weak 3Q 2019 guidance given these revenue and cost pressures. In
either case, we believe these potentially negative data points could shift investor focus back
towards Twitter’s extreme valuation, which would not be good news for the stock.
Further, we believe slowing growth and rising costs could be a burden on Twitter for years to
come. Twitter’s user base is small and only growing in the single digits domestically and lowdouble digits internationally. So, we do not believe user metrics will be able to support
continued top-line growth above +20% into the future. Also, Twitter is already monetizing its
users at relatively strong rates compared to its Internet peers, leaving less room for upside.
Direct response advertising to attract the long tail of SMBs remains a longer-term opportunity,
but we are skeptical Twitter will have enough users or user data to create granularly targeted
audiences for each small business. Further, we expect cost growth could very well remain
elevated as Twitter confronts the reality that cleaning up its platform is quite a challenge.

JP11:58am

After factoring in lower revenue growth due to tough 3Q comps, as well as higher cost growth for
the rest of the year, we are lowering our 2019 GAAP EBITDA estimate by -12%. We maintain
our target 2020E GAAP EBITDA multiple at 14x, and lower our target price to $25 (vs. $28
previously), representing -33% downside to Twitter’s last closing price of $37.
